column3: There has never been a verified scientific report that chelation therapy, a gluten-free diet, or anything else can cure autism.

I've pretty much always been on a diet since I was born. And the women in my family struggle, so I find the less I think about food, in a way, the happier I am. In general, I think I eat less the less I think about it.
I get a delivery of a diet food during the week, which doesn't mean that I don't eat the occasional Krispy Kreme doughnut.

It's really unfair to working women in America who read celebrity news and think, 'Why can't I lose weight when I've had a baby?' Well, everyone you're reading about has money for a trainer and a chef. That doesn't make it realistic.
I pay attention to my diet to be a healthier gymnast, but I'm not obsessive over it.
Sometimes I've had to put myself on a diet.

Once in a while, I'll slip and get off my vegan diet and have egg whites in the morning, that's a good source of protein while I'm out on the road. If I can feel my body starting to tire, those are good to keep you healthy.
I would eat healthy at times and pig out at times. But I never had to go on a strict diet plan.

Unless you're living on the street and surviving on a diet of discarded turkey drumsticks, there's no point in being gloomy. We've spent too long trying to cheer ourselves up by spending money on brightly coloured things we don't really need. We've stopped using our imaginations.
As people move further away from a meat-based diet, I think the focus will shift to using grains as the central focus of our food supply.
The diet for climbing all the time isn't really different from the diet for living. It's not like cardio sports where you're burning a bajillion calories every day.
I love healthy stuff and junk an equal amount. Whatever I'm craving, I go for it. I'm never trying to lose weight - or gain it. I'm just being.
I've tried just about every crazy diet you can imagine.
I try to eat fruit and veggies and meat and all the different categories and have a well rounded diet.
Pizza is no longer on my diet.
I have been on a diet since 1962.
I do practice what I preach when it comes to nutrition.
But I don't do the diet thing anymore. I'm a big believer in feeding your body what it needs. Deny yourself something and you're going to end up shoving your face full of it.
Food is an important part of a balanced diet.
I try to not be too hard on myself regarding my diet. I've always been a workout-to-eat kind of a girl.
I try to not be too hard on myself regarding my diet. I've always been a workout-to-eat kind of a girl. I like to eat, to say the least.

But I can only take so much TV, because there is so much advice. I find people will preach about virtually anything - your diet, how to live your life, how to improve your golf. The lot. I have always had a thing against the Mister Know-It-Alls.

My diet, my regime, the whole life I have on the road has always got that little bit of stress because I'm always afraid I'm going to get a cold. And it's just such a nightmare when you got a cold or an irritation and you have to do a show.
For my diet, I choose mostly organic. But in general, I am a big believer in trying to strike a balance with everything.

I grew up in North Carolina, and they have a soft drink called Sun Drop. I love the diet version of it. It's the greatest thing on the face of the earth. I always have it in my fridge - bus fridge and home fridge.
The best diet is the one that can be sustained over the long term, combined with other healthful lifestyle behaviors.
